entry.et: Middle English ferm, from Anglo-French, from Latin firmus; akin to Greek thronos chair, throne

def.dt: :having a solid or compact structure that resists stress or pressure
:indicating firmness or resolution a firm mouth
:to make secure or fast :tighten firming her grip on the racquet often used with up
:to make solid or compact firm the soil
:to put into final form :settle firm a contract firm up plans
:to give additional support to :strengthen usually used with up
:to become firm :harden often used with up
:to recover from a decline :improve the market is firming

entry.et: German Firma, from Italian, signature, ultimately from Latin firmare to make firm, confirm, from firmus

def.dt: :the name or title under which a company transacts business
:a partnership of two or more persons that is not recognized as a legal person distinct from the members composing it
